unnormalised: The new flyover near Hebbal in Bangalore is causing quite a stir, mainly 'cause of the delays. They’d initially promised it'd be done by 31/12/2023, but looks like it's gonna take longer. Folks are saying the current construction is using about 2000 metric tons of steel.
normalised: The new flyover near Hebbal in Bangalore is causing quite a stir, mainly because of the delays. They had initially promised it would be done by thirty first december two thousand and twenty three, but looks like it is going to take longer. Folks are saying the current construction is using about two thousand metric tons of steel.

unnormalised: Apparently, the initial plan was to build it with pillars spaced 25 meters apart, but they had to make some changes due to soil conditions or something. Now, the word is they’re pouring around 5000 cubic meters of concrete for the foundation alone. The estimated cost has also jumped from ₹75 crore to almost ₹90 crore!
normalised: Apparently, the initial plan was to build it with pillars spaced twenty five meters apart, but they had to make some changes due to soil conditions or something. Now, the word is they are pouring around five thousand cubic meters of concrete for the foundation alone. The estimated cost has also jumped from rupee seventy five crore to almost rupee ninety crore!

unnormalised: Commuters are really feeling the pinch. The travel time during peak hours has increased by at least 30 mins. Let’s hope they speed things up and finish it soon, before the monsoon starts and things get even more chaotic, especially considering the flyover's length is said to be roughly 1.8 km.
normalised: Commuters are really feeling the pinch. The travel time during peak hours has increased by at least thirty minutes. Let us hope they speed things up and finish it soon, before the monsoon starts and things get even more chaotic, especially considering the flyover's length is said to be roughly one point eight kilometer.
